                    Anhydrous Ammonia System
                      Risk Management Plan
                        Executive Summary
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                                
                            June 2004
                              
                  ANHYDROUS AMMONIA SYSTEM
                              
           RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1    Chemical Accident Prevention and Emergency Response
   Policy

It  is  the  policy of the Engelhard Corporation  Attapulgus
Operations (Engelhard) facility management to implement  the
requirements   of  this  Risk  Management  Plan   (RMP)   in
accordance  with the EPA regulations under 40 CFR  Part  68.
Engelhard's objective is to minimize the risk of  a  release
of  anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) and, if a release occurs, to
minimize the potential impact to Engelhard's employees,  the
public,   and  the  environment.  This  objective  will   be
accomplished by utilizing general good operating  practices,
providing  appropriate training to all employees,  complying
with   pertinent  codes  and  regulations,  and  proactively
planning and coordinating emergency response activities with
Engelhard's local emergency response providers.

Engelhard's   management  is  committed  to  providing   the
resources necessary to implement

this policy.


2    Facility Description

Engelhard manufactures petroleum catalysts, including  fluid
cracking  and  moving  bed  catalysts,  for  sale   to   oil
refineries.  As part of this process, Engelhard uses ammonia
for   pH  control  in  various  applications  in  sufficient
quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR  Part
68,  Chemical  Accident Prevention Provisions.   Engelhard
has one 12,000-gal ammonia storage tank.


3    General Chemical Accident Prevention Program and
   Ammonia-Specific Prevention Steps

Engelhard  is  governed  by  a set  of  MSHA  and  EPA  (and
corresponding Georgia) regulations that require a number  of
activities  intended  to  prevent  a  release  of  hazardous
materials, or if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize
the  consequences of a release to the facility's  employees,
the  public, and the environment. Some of these MSHA and EPA
regulations include:

     ú    30 CFR Part 56, Safety and Health Standards-Surface
       Metal and Nonmetal Mines
     ú    40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions
     ú    40 CFR Part 110, Discharge of Oil
     ú    40 CFR Part 112, Oil Pollution Prevention
     ú    40 CFR Part 117, Determination of Reportable Quantities
       for Hazardous Substances
     ú    40 CFR Part 122, EPA-Administered Permit Programs: The
       National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System
     ú    40 CFR Part 262,  Standards Applicable to Generators of
       Hazardous Waste
     ú     40  CFR Part 302, Designation, Notification,  and
       Reportable Quantities
     ú    40 CFR Part 355, Emergency Planning and Notification

In  particular, Engelhard has instituted an ammonia-specific
accident   prevention  program  in  conformance   with   the
provisions  of 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident  Prevention
Provisions,  and Georgia's Rules of Safety Fire Commissioner
Chapter 120-3-12, Rules and Regulations for the Storage  and
H

andling of Anhydrous Ammonia.  Key concepts of this program
include  periodic Process Hazard Analyses (PHA),  up-to-date
operations   and   maintenance  procedures   and   training,
Management  of  Change  and  Pre-Startup  Review  processes,
periodic compliance audits and incident investigations,  and
employee participation in site safety processes.


3.1  Process Hazard Analyses

A multi-departmental team of Engelhard employees recently
conducted an ammonia system Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) in
June 2004 using current Process Safety Information.  The PHA
was designed to proactively identify and address any system
weaknesses in order to prevent accidental ammonia releases.
Items identified were documented and appropriate work orders
submitted.  Procedures are in place to maintain this PHA
consistent with the current ammonia process and to update
and revalidate it at least every five years.


3.2  Procedures and Training

It  is  Engelhard's policy to ensure that its employees  are
provided clear instructions for safely conducting all  work-
related activities.  Accordingly, the ammonia system  has  a
set of related standard operating procedures (SOPs) and safe
work  practices.   Employees operating  the  ammonia  system
receive  various forms of training in these  SOPs  and  safe
work  practices  to  ensure that they  have  the  knowledge,
skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties.

It is also Engelhard's policy to inspect, test, and maintain
its process equipment in a manner consistent with applicable
manufacturer's    recommendations   and   recognized    good
engineering practices.  Accordingly, Engelhard has  ammonia-
related   maintenance  procedures  addressing   preventative
maintenance  and repairs, hot work permits, etc designed  to
prevent  accidental ammonia releases.  Maintenance mechanics
and   technicians  receive  appropriate  training  in  these
procedures  to ensure that they have the knowledge

,  skills,
and  abilities  to  safely  carry  out  their  duties.    In
addition,  Engelhard works with its maintenance  contractors
to ensure that they are familiar with and meet or exceed all
site safety standards and practices.


3.3  Management of Change and Pre-Startup Review Processes

Engelhard management recognizes that processes and equipment
constantly change.  To ensure that these changes are managed
and  implemented safely, Engelhard has Management of  Change
and  Pre-Startup Review processes in place  to  ensure  that
safety and health considerations and procedural and training
requirements  are addressed in conjunction with  any  change
being implemented.


3.4  Compliance Audits and Incident Investigations

Engelhard  conducts routine audits of its  ammonia  accident
prevention program to ensure the program's effectiveness and
continuous improvement.  However, should an ammonia  release
occur,  Engelhard  has  an  Incident  Investigation  process
designed  to  quickly identify root causes  and  appropriate
actions  to  prevent future releases.  These  investigations
are reviewed regularly for trends, etc as a means of further
managing the safety of Engelhard's manufacturing processes.


3.5  Employee Participation

Engelhard's ultimate goal is to achieve an injury-free
workplace.  An ongoing objective in support of this goal is
to include all employees in all facets of safety.
Participation in site safety efforts is therefore expected
and rewarded.  Employees participate in various safety
processes such as Workplace Inspections, Behavioral Safety
Observations, Job Safety Analyses, Root Cause Analyses,
Process Hazard Analysis, etc.


4    Five Year Accident History

Engelhard has had no releases of ammonia that have  affected
onsite personnel, the public, or the environment in the past
five years.


5    Emergency Response Program

Engelhard does not have onsite emergency response capability
to  respo

nd  to  an  ammonia  emergency.  Therefore,  it  is
Engelhard's  policy to contact offsite emergency  responders
for assistance in the event of an ammonia-related emergency.

In  the  event of a non-emergency ammonia release, Engelhard
employees  trained  in  the safe operation  of  the  ammonia
system  will close automatic shutoff valves (and  manual  if
these  can  be safely approached) to terminate the  flow  of
ammonia.

For all other scenarios, Engelhard's employees will evacuate
the area as necessary and allow offsite responders - in this
case   representatives  of  the  Decatur  County   Emergency
Management  Agency and Decatur County Fire Department  -  to
respond to the ammonia emergency.


6    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Engelhard is making changes to improve the safety of its
ammonia system, including:

    ú    Reviewing and revising the ammonia system relief valve
      preventive maintenance program as necessary
    ú    Reviewing and revising the ammonia system engineering
      drawings as necessary
    ú    Installing additional safeguards such as low tank level
      alarms
    ú    Isolating/Demolishing obsolete/inactive sections of the
      ammonia pipeline system

These changes will be in place by August 2004.
